I have a few questions: Does every CPU cut its instruction set in half? Half for opcode, half for RAM addresses? This design would bottleneck how much RAM can actually be used right?  How does a 32 bit processor handle 4GB of RAM if, by this video's CPU design, half of the instruction set is for addresses (32/2 = 16bits, 16 bits = 65000ish addresses?  If the address bus going to the RAM is 4 wires, it can address 16 different addresses in the RAM but if the program instructions are only 8 bits and an instruction is half op code and half memory addresses (4 bits & 4 bits), that would mean this CPU can only handle 16 different addresses with its 8 bit instruction reg. So a program can only be 16 instructions long. Even if the address bus is bigger, say 8 bits wide instead of 4, and now it can handle 256 different addresses of RAM, this CPU's 8 bit instruction reg would then be a bottleneck as it can still only handle 4 bits (16 memory locations) of memory addresses when executing instructions because it's instruction register can only hold 8 bits.   Where I'm coming from is, a 32 bit processor can handle 4GB of RAM addresses. Which means the entire instruction set has to be a memory address. If only half a 32 bit processor instruction reg was used for memory addresses, like in this video's example CPU design, you'd only get 65500-ish memory addresses. Which doesn't make sense because a 32 bit processor can handle 4GB. I know this video is a simple (I use simple loosely) example of the foundational principles of a CPU. I'm trying to bridge a gap in what I'm understanding (hope I'm understanding rather lol) is all. Any help would be appreciated! Thank you for these videos, I refer to them all of the time!

This topic is also fundamental in understanding how security vulnerabilities emerge, how operating systems become CPU specific, and your options when considering whether you can virtualize or must emulate an OS. The CPU itself doesn't know what parts of the call stack it should be allowed to execute so it's up to the kernel to protect the call stack from corruption by, say, a buffer overflow vulnerability (overwriting the stack with your own opcodes by exploiting a lack of bounds checking), which in user space is largely left to the app developer to prevent. ARM instruction sets != Intel IS' so you won't be able to, say, run Trisquel Linux on ARM without compiling it and any BLOB dependencies yourself, as far as I know anyway. Then, you're limited to applications compiled & linked to use Linux kernel executable binary format and system calls (ELF). If your OS is a virtual image then it can either utilize the underlying hardware or depend on an emulated environment or somewhere in-between. And it all comes back to CPU instruction sets.

Jules Webb a computer program just starts at zero (in context of virtual memory which is an abstraction at the level of the operating system) and just counts up thanks to a special circuit in the CPU that counts up one number every time the clock triggers. (Imagine an adder circuit that always adds one to its current output) Special instructions called JUMP or BRANCH instructions can override this incremental counter, called the program counter, to allow programs to freely pick what part they are executing. This is the basis of functional programming

Jules Webb then you have a bug that you need to take out of your program. In a properly working program, you will not have junk instructions. Debugging hardware makes it possible to check each instruction as it is executed

Usually in the first or second semester of computer science (YMMV. I'm from Canada).

The control unit sends several signals to the rest of the CPU and to the memory. So it can tell the content of the Instruction Address Register to go to the address pins of the memory during the fetch phase and tell the four lower bits of the Instruction Register itself to go to the address pins of the memory during the execute phase, for example. It can tell Register A to store what is coming from the memory data pins during one clock cycle and to do nothing in the next clock cycle.  But how it this actually done? There are several circuits that can generate these complicated sequence of signals. One option is called a "finite state machine" which has a few storage bits to indicate the "current state" and some logic gates that calculate the "next state" as well as the values of all the control signals. On each clock the next state value is stored into the current state.  An alternative is to use a memory circuit. This is called a "microcoded" design because the memory and the "microcode counter" that addresses it are like a very tiny and simple computer inside a larger one. Think of this memory as the cylinder in an ancient mechanical music box where spinning the cylinder is like incrementing the microcode counter and it bit in memory is like a place on the cylinder which may either have a pin to play the corresponding note or may be flat, in which case that particular note doesn't play at that particular moment.

Yeah... it's one of those things you take for granted, untill you need to implement it yourself :) You'd need to do number system conversion, kinda like you would do yourself on paper. For converting binary number X to decimal, you can do X mod 10 (remainder of division by 10) and that would give you last (least significant) digit. Then you do integer divide by 10, effectively removing the last digit from number, ie. 123 / 10 = 12 (remainder 3). Repeat until you've reached zero, and print all the remainders in reverse order.

My problem is I either use more than 16 bits to make room for opcode or I just cant access all of the 64kb that 16 bit computer is suppose to access.

x86 instruction set, for example, has instructions ranging from 1 to 6 bytes. They don't need to be register-sized, nor all the same length. If you need them to be the same length, or just shorter in general, then you can set up some sort of segmentation, where you set a kind of "bookmark" in 64k increments with one 16 bit value (you'd have an instruction and/or a register just for manipulating that value), and then with another 16 bit value you say which byte you want, relative to that mark. That scheme would give you access to 4 GB of RAM. Since memory usage is usually clustered together, you wouldn't need to change that "bookmark" (segment register) often, most of the time you'd just play around in that one 64k chunk (segment), like it's the only memory you have, then you'd move over to another chunk, etc. You could scale this down a bit if you really want all your instructions to be 16 bit (fit in both the opcode and an address).

you could also design your instructions to only fetch 32 bit lines and no smaller. your data would have to stored at addresses that are multiples of four bytes (4×8=32), which means the last two bits of the addresses you can fetch would always be 00. the instruction therefore wouldn't need to specify those two bits, they would be implied, saving two whole bits! yay :)

You may be interested in downloading a CPU emulator, which will let you experiment with machine and assembly code.  Do you already know Java, or are you learning that at the same time as CPU architectures? If the latter, then coding a CPU may confuse you more than help.   If you already know Java though, consider these things: -How are you loading from RAM? Are you splitting the 16-bit instructions into "op-code" and "address" sections? If so, try instead storing the address you want to load from RAM in its own register. Assuming you have 16 registers, then you could use the first 8 bits for your op-code, the next 4 bits as the register number containing the RAM address you want to load from, and the last 4 bits as the register number you want to load the data into. This way you can load from all 2^16 memory addresses. -How are you representing binary data? If you're using primitives, Java (I believe) will interpret them as signed integers when using them to index arrays. So a Java variable of type "byte" will never be greater than 127, even though 2^8 = 256. Similarly with chars, ints, etc...

Its just an example based on the 4004 chip. There are other strategies to deal with address, instructions and data. The 8086 (from with the current Intel and Amd desktop chips are decendents) that were a 16 bit CPU uses a 16 bits for receiving data from the CPU and 20 bits to address the memory. I can be wrong, but i think in some architectures is possible that one 'clock' loads the instruction and other clock the address(es), so you could have 256 different instructions and 256 different addresses. Some time ago there are also the concept of segment, if i'm not wrong, first you select a segment, after that the address inside the segment, a segment would be like a district when you send an letter, to use a address from another segment you would need to change the segment first. In general there are some 'RAM ADDRESS' that aren't in fact RAM, those are the address to write (and read) from external devices.

Modern CPUs have multi-byte instructions. So the first byte could be a modifier (e.g. switch the instruction between 16- and 32-bit mode, or between 32- and 64-bit). The next byte is the opcode of the instruction; part of it also might identify the registers involved (e.g. which register is being loaded or stored to memory). The next 4 (or 8) bytes might contain the 32-bit (or 64-bit) memory address involved. Further bytes may involve additional parameters as necessary.  Also, sometimes even more memory addressing is possible via mechanisms like paging. For example, 16-bit CPUs would technically only support 64K of memory, but Intel 8086 could address a whole megabyte by adding extra 16-bit segment registers, whose value would combine with the 16-bit memory offset to form a 20-bit address (the segment value is multiplied by 16 and then added to the offset, thus basically giving you 4 extra bits for a 20-bit effective memory address). So for example, if the segment register contains 0, you're accessing a 16-bit offset into the first 64-kilobyte page of memory. If the segment contains 2000 hex, you're accessing addresses 2XXXX hex (or the third 64-kilobyte page).  32-bit CPUs (Intel 80386) introduced even further levels of indirection by introducing global and local descriptor tables. So for example, now the 16-bit segment register is a "selector" (index) into the descriptor table, which contains the 32-bit starting address of the segment into which we're addressing (in theory allowing you to address up to 256T of memory). Different processes could also have different descriptor tables mapping into different physical addresses, so each 32-bit process can address a separate memory space and be isolated from others. And so on. It's really cool if you're interested.

maklas if you do operations with 16-bit registers, then you've designed a 16-bit CPU 😊 But yeah, this is fascinating. There are also two fundamentally different approaches to CPU design - CISC (complex instruction set computing), used by regular computers, where you have big CPUs with complex instructions like this, or RISC (reduced instruction set computing), used by phones or other smaller devices, where you have only a very basic set of instructions, each of which usually executes very fast, though. The former allows for more computational power, given that it's no longer easy to achieve any higher clock speeds, but at the cost of a complex and expensive CPU; the latter gives you cheaper and more power-efficient CPUs (given that they require many fewer transistors), at the cost of potentially slower programs due to requiring more instructions to do the same thing as a single CISC instruction could do.  So your design skills might be fine for designing the CPU of a TV remote or microwave 😊

A cache is basically another kind of memory used to hold some information without having to constantly access the RAM. Modern computers can kind of look ahead of what the next instructions will do. For example you have RAM addresses 1 through 10, and the instructions will be that the numbers stored in there will be added together and written back into 1. Essentially the instructions are "Add the value in 1 and the value in X together. Store the result to 1" for X = 2 through 10. Instead of doing this every time and having to write to 1, you instead write to a cache adress and fetch again from the cache adress until the last instruction when you write back to 1.  This is done because the cache is implemented inside the CPU, meaning that accessing the cache is much faster than accessing the RAM.

Computer designers look for a few metrics for memory devices: speed, memory size, and cost. Unfortunately, there are tradeoffs between the 3. You can't have terabytes of incredibly fast memory on the cheap.  However, most programs only need a small amount of memory at a time. Computers store all of the information they might need out in slow, big, cheap memory. Then, as they need that information, they pull it into faster memory, called cache. They do everything they need to do in the fast memory (cache), then send the results back out into slow memory. The goal is to never have to read the same information twice out of the slow memory, and to never write to the slow memory information that you are going to overwrite later anyway.  The processor has even faster memory, called registers, that were featured in the video. These registers are to cache as the cache is to the slow disk. The registers are the working memory that the processor operates on before sending the information back out to the cache.  Using fast memory to temporarily store information, so that you don't have to wait for the slower memory as often, is called caching.

I never said to get rid of analogies. I said to get rid of meaningless analogies. The Roman Galley analogy is an awful "analogy" because there is only 1 superficial connection; both involve speeding up. That's like saying "Humans are like dogs, they both have eyes". Likewise saying "Overclocking is like a Roman Galley speeding up, they both speed up" is really an awful analogy. Sure it sounds cool, because ROMAN GALLEY RAMMING A SHIP! but it provides no insight, and in fact is arguably misleading.   It's misleading because the Roman Galley speeds up because it encounters a ship. This is far different than overclocking; in general, overclocking doesn't occur solely when a CPU intensive demand pops up, which is what the Roman Galley analogy would suggest. A Roman Galley only speeds up when it encounters a problem, whereas CPU overclocking is more of a general thing, not a situational and dynamic thing.  An example of a better analogy might be a factory instead. If a factory ramps up production, not only does that parallel faster clock speeds, but there are many other aspects that also parallel each other such as increased strain on workers which is comparable to increased heat and energy requirements, potential consequences due to both systems working harder than originally intended, et cetera.  Analogies are supposed to explain or clarify something. Not just point out that 2 different things have merely 1 similar aspect, but everything else is completely different.

The "level of abstraction" is a very important and very real concept in computer engineering and computer science.  It allows you to interface with components at a higher level while allowing those components to change and become more efficient without changing their outwards facing interface, thereby allowing you to swap one component with another without interfering with what task you're trying to get done.  The "level of abstraction" is there to show you that when you're programming or designing these machines, you don't need to think about how bits are moving through them, for the most part.  For example, you don't need to think about how your program is laid out in physical memory and how it's layout relates to the layout of other running programs  because virtual memory is a "layer of abstraction" that presents all programs with the full layout of memory.  This "layer of abstraction" can even apply to individual machines across networks.  For example, if you were trying to access a resource from the network, you don't need to think about how the resources are distributed because there is a "layer of abstraction" that you communicate with that handles the distribution behind the scenes and allows to just communicate with that layer to get your resource.

Hence why I say "Everything is abstraction", but at the same time it's meaningless when examining individual components. The way it's being used is merely as a catch phrase, rather than mentioning abstraction in its actual application.

I'm not sure you understand that abstraction is very meaningful and not meaningless.  When designing logic circuits, the designers don't deal with the transistor circuits, they deal with the abstract symbols for logical operations to create and improve upon the bigger component they're trying to design.  Someone else works on improving the individual transistor designs that make up those abstract symbols for logical operations independent of the designers working with just the abstract symbols.  This abstraction is very real and very meaningful.

Abstraction is meaningful, but what's not meaningful is saying "this is ground, another layer of abstraction!", "this is capacitor, another layer of abstraction!", "this is an AND gate, another layer of abstraction!".  Understanding what abstraction is is meaningful. Using it at every opportunity for no purpose other than to try and force a catch phrase is not meaningful. You're clearly arguing something that nobody denied; I didn't say learning about abstraction is meaningless, but rather I'm saying that using that phrase because it sounds techy and catchy is meaningless. Explaining how something is abstraction, and how it's useful and makes life easier for people using something is meaningful. These videos don't really do that; they explain WHAT something is, then say "another layer of abstraction" which isn't helpful because they're not elaborating by giving examples of how abstraction works, and how it's being used.

For extra credit, try writing an emulator for this virtual cpu. Emulators are commonly thought of as either development tools to do things like run an android app you're working on on your PC, or to play games for old game consoles, but emulation itself is just the act of using a piece of software to act like a particular piece of hardware. Many components of an emulator directly mirror those of a physical CPU. In addition, just because the CPU in this video doesn't exist in hardware, doesn't mean you can't emulate it. In some ways, the Java Virtual Machine acts like an emulator that treats Java Bytecode as its machine code.

Multiplexers and demultiplexers are just fancy applications of AND gates. A multiplexer is just Output = (A and Select) OR (B and not Select) A demultiplexer is O1 = Input and Select, O2 = Input and not Select For more branches, you just need to test more select bits, and for wider words, you just need to duplicate to circuit for each bit.

+Recurve - Multicore support is very widespread. It's true that a lot of games (by which I mean console ports) don't use more than four cores, but that just means you've still got four cores available for background tasks, and don't suffer framerate dips everytime a background program needs a bit of processing power. Also, outside of gaming the benefits are legio; you simply don't want to know how quickly my SolidWorks renders are done now, with sixteen threads working away at it...

Robert Faber Exactly! Multithreaded code is far more difficult to write and therefore less commonly used, which many people use to discount AMD's focus on high thread count. But once you've done the hard work of getting it multithreaded in the first place, it's often trivial to scale thread use based on hardware, so nearly all multithreaded applications are significantly faster on high thread count processors.  But even in games, high core count can be a huge help. For example, my game's n-body gravity and procedural planet generation algorithms are designed to use a flexible thread count, so core count has massive performance impact. As these are some of the most computationally intensive processes in my game, Ryzen runs it far better.

+Ang Robins At 2:02 you can see that the instructions are written on what opcode loads to which register.  And on the how, if you want to load to register A, you run the opcode trough some logic gates that send out a true if it's 0010 and the output is connected to the "write enable" of that registry, same for register B but it checks for 0001. The CPU sends the value to all registers, but only register A or B will write it because only one of them has the "write enable" input true.
